doc.previous: The police deterred and contained opposition to party directives.[74] The political police served as the core of the system, with their names becoming synonymous with raw power and the threat of violent retribution should an individual become active against the collective.[74] Several state police and secret police organizations enforced communist party rule, including:
doc.after: The press in the communist period was an organ of the state, completely reliant on and subservient to the communist party.[75] Before the late 1980s, Eastern Bloc radio and television organizations were state-owned, while print media was usually owned by political organizations, mostly by the local communist party.[76] Youth newspapers and magazines were owned by youth organizations affiliated with communist parties.[76]
